ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Influence of H2O/DEZ ratio on LPCVD ZnO:B films for application in a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H tandem solar cells

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Chemistry and Material Science
Affiliation.OrgName: Hunan Institute of Humanities, Science and Technology

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Laboratories of Polar Materials and Devices

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
In this study, boron doped zinc oxide (ZnO:B) films were prepared at different water to diethyl zinc (H2O/DEZ) flow ratios from 0.6 to 1.4 by a low pressure chemical vapor deposition (LPCVD) technique. It is found that the morphology of ZnO:B films varies from small leaf-like to pyramidal surface structures with the increasing H2O/DEZ flow ratio. The rough ZnO:B films deposited at a relatively H2O/DEZ flow ratio such as 1.2 or 1.4 show a high haze value of up to 28Â % at 600 nm and
$\mathrm{a} (11\overline{2}0)$ preferential crystallographic orientation. All ZnO:B films were applied in hydrogenated amorphous silicon/microcrystalline silicon tandem solar cells (a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H) as front electrodes. The efficiency of the solar cells increases with the increasing H2O/DEZ flow ratio, which is attributed to a high spectral response mainly in the long-wavelength range and the consequent enhancement of short-circuit current. A high-efficiency a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H tandem solar cell of 10Â % was achieved. The H2O/DEZ ratio is an important process parameter to tune the material properties of LPCVD ZnO:B films and the performances of corresponding silicon thin film solar cells.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Boron doped zinc oxide (ZnO:B) films are widely used as transparent conductive oxide (TCO) electrodes in high efficiency silicon thin film solar cells due to their good optical and electrical properties as well as rough surface structures [1â5]. In addition, ZnO:B films are applied as an intermediate reflective layer as a SiO x layer to enhance the light absorption [6, 7]. Several research groups have systematically investigated the influences of deposition temperature, process pressure, doping concentration and film thickness on the ZnO:B films prepared by low pressure chemical vapor deposition (LPCVD) [2, 3, 8â13] and atmospheric pressure chemical vapor deposition (APCVD)Â [14]. The optical and electrical properties, grain structure and morphology are strongly dependent on these deposition conditions. In the mean time, the performances of solar cells strongly relied on these properties of ZnO:B films like morphology, light scattering and absorption when they are applied in silicon thin film solar cells as front electrodes [2, 8, 10]. In addition, Ding etÂ al.Â [15] reported LPCVD ZnO bilayers obtained by changing the doping level especially for application in silicon thin film solar cells and high photogenerated currents were achieved. Recently, the flow ratio of water to diethyl zinc (H2O/DEZ) was reported to tune the morphology and electrical properties of LPCVD ZnO:B films as front electrodes of the silicon thin film solar cellsÂ [16]. The morphology varies from small grains with a few larger pyramidal grains to large pyramidal grains and then to slightly smaller pyramidal grains with the increasing H2O/DEZ ratio from 0.9 to 5.2. However, different variations of morphology and other optical and electrical properties of ZnO:B films different from the observations in the literature [16] were observed by us even though similar deposition conditions were employed, which may be related with diluted gas and carrier gas, hydrogen (H2). Furthermore, all LPCVD ZnO:B films here were applied in hydrogenated amorphous silicon/microcrystalline silicon tandem solar cells (a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H) as front electrodes. It is found that the ZnO:B films deposited at H2O/DEZ flow ratios of more than 1 can provide a high light trapping effect and a good solar cell performance.

In this study, the influence of the flow ratio of H2O/DEZ on LPCVD ZnO:B films is systematically investigated. Optical and electrical properties, crystallographic orientation and morphology of the ZnO:B films were characterized by spectrophotometry, Hall effect, X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) measurements.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para:
The ZnO:B films were prepared on 3.2Â mm large area float glasses (1.1Â mÃ1.3Â m) by the LPVCD technique (TCO 1200 from Oerlikon Solar company). H2O and DEZ were used as main precursor gases and evaporated in individual evaporation tanks. The temperature for DEZ and H2O bubblers in the tanks was about 60Â Â°C. The H2O/DEZ flow ratio was changed from 0.6 to 1.4 by reducing the H2O vapor flow while keeping the DEZ flow constant (2700Â sccm). Hydrogen-diluted diborane (B2H6) gas was used as doping resource and the B2H6/DEZ flow ratio was kept at 0.08. In addition, more pure H2 gas (550Â sccm) was input to accelerate the internal thermal balance during the reaction. The thicknesses of ZnO:B films at different H2O/DEZ ratios are between 1130 nm and 1740Â nm. The substrate temperature was controlled at around 150Â Â°C by heating with resistance wires. The working pressure was 0.5Â mbar. These LPCVD ZnO:B films were applied in a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H solar cells as front electrodes. The thicknesses of intrinsic a-Si:H and Î¼c-Si:H layers were 180Â nm and 850Â nm, respectively. The same LPCVD ZnO:B films with a slightly heavy doping level were used as back electrodes for all solar cells. A thin SiO x film served in the tandem solar cells as intermediate reflective (IMR) layer to adjust the light absorptions between the top and bottom cells. Moreover, white polyvinyl butyral (PVB) dielectric foils were employed as highly reflective encapsulation foils. FigureÂ 1 shows the configuration of the a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H solar cells studied here.
Fig.Â 1
Configuration of the a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H solar cells. A thin SiO x film served in the tandem solar cells as intermediate reflective (IMR) layer. White polyvinyl butyral (PVB) dielectric foils were employed as highly reflective encapsulation foils

The thicknesses of the ZnO:B films were measured by an optical test system (XYT v1.1 from Oerlikon Solar company). The morphologies of the ZnO:B films were investigated using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, S4800). The crystallographic orientation was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement in the BraggâBrentano geometry (Î¸â2Î¸). Cu KÎ± X-rays (1.5418Â Ã ) were produced under an accelerating voltage of 30 kV and a current of 40Â mA. The electrical properties were checked by Hall measurement using the Van der Pauw configuration at room temperature. The optical properties of the ZnO:B films and solar cells involving total transmission (TT), diffuse transmission (DT) and total reflection (TR) were measured by a spectrophotometer mounted with an integrating sphere (Perkin Elmer Lambda 950). The light scattering property, i.e. haze, was defined as DT/TT. The currentâvoltage (IâV) curves of solar cells were measured by an IâV test system under the standard test conditions (25Â Â°C, 1000Â W/m2, AM1.5). The area of all solar cells is 1Â cm2. The spectral responses for the top cells and bottom cells of tandem solar cells were characterized through external quantum efficiency (EQE) measurement.

Section2.Heading: Various properties of LPCVD ZnO:B films
Section2.Para:
FigureÂ 2 shows the morphologies of the ZnO:B films prepared at different H2O/DEZ ratios from 0.6 to 1.4. The thicknesses of the ZnO:B films at different H2O/DEZ ratios are as follows: 1130 nm (0.6), 1460 nm (0.8), 1680 nm (1.0), 1740 nm (1.2) and 1720 nm (1.4). When the H2O/DEZ ratio is 0.6, the ZnO:B films show a small and long leaf-shape topography as shown in Fig.Â 2a. The small and long leaf-shape morphology turns into a similar leaf-shape but large morphology when the H2O/DEZ ratio is increased to 0.8 as shown in Fig.Â 2b. Differently, the morphology of ZnO:B films is varied from leaf-shape to tetragonal or pyramidal surface structures as the H2O/DEZ ratio increases to 1.0 as shown in Fig.Â 2c. Furthermore, when the H2O/DEZ ratio increases to 1.2 and 1.4, the ZnO:B films show pyramid surface structures with larger tetragonal grains as shown in Fig.Â 2d, which were observed by other researchers [2, 3]. Even though the film thickness affects the feature size of surface structures to some extent, the corresponding shapes of surface structures will not change. Note that the SEM image of the ZnO:B films grown at an H2O/DEZ ratio of 1.2 is not shown here. However, it was reported that an even higher H2O/DEZ ratio would lead to small-size pyramidal morphologies and a low light scattering as well as other different electrical and optical propertiesÂ [17]. It was also reported that the process pressure and doping gas can lead to different sizes of surface structures other than the grain shape [2, 9]. Furthermore, the substrate temperature is an important deposition condition to fabricate ZnO:B films with different types of morphologies [3, 11, 13]. Low substrate temperature (130Â Â°C) leads to the formation of relatively flat ZnO:B films with small grainsÂ [3]. Then the morphology varies from small grains with a few large-size pyramidal grains to large-size pyramidal grains when the substrate temperature increases from 146Â Â°C to 164Â Â°C. Then it changes to relatively small pyramidal grains and disordered shapes as the substrate temperature increases from 180Â°C to 236Â Â°CÂ [3]. Such a change in morphology could be due to the thermal kinetic energies of the molecules on the surface as well as different preferential growth directions in the films at different growth temperatures. Nicolay et al. observed that the morphology varies from small grains with a few larger pyramidal grains to large pyramidal grains and then to slightly smaller pyramidal grains with increasing H2O/DEZ ratio from 0.9 to 5.2Â [16]. Such an observation in variation of morphology at H2O/DEZ ratios from 0.9 to 1.15 in the literatureÂ [16] is different from what we mentioned above, which could be due to the inputting of the H2 acted as diluted gas in the B2H6 mixture gas and carrier gas mentioned in the experimental section. In Ref.Â [16], 1Â % B2H6 in argon was used and its flow was adapted to achieve a similar carrier concentration while 2Â % B2H6 in H2 is kept constant here and in the mean time H2 gas of 550 sccm was added to accelerate the internal thermal balance inside the reaction chamber during the film growth. The H2 may affect the growth of ZnO:B films to some extent. The exact cause is not clear so far and deep investigations of such a kind of influence will be carried out in the near future.
Fig.Â 2
Morphologies of the ZnO:B films prepared at different H2O/DEZ ratios: (a)Â 0.6, (b)Â 0.8, (c)Â 1.0 and (d)Â 1.4. The thicknesses of ZnO:B films at different H2O/DEZ ratios are as follows: 1130Â nm (0.6), 1460Â nm (0.8), 1680Â nm (1.0), 1740Â nm (1.2) and 1720Â nm (1.4)

ZnO:B films deposited at different H2O/DEZ flow ratios show different electrical properties as shown in Fig.Â 4. As shown in Fig.Â 4a, the resistivity first drastically decreases by one order of magnitude from 2.3Ã10â2Â Î©âcm to 2.1Ã10â3Â Î©âcm when the H2O/DEZ flow ratio increases from 0.6 to 1.0. As the H2O/DEZ flow ratio increases further from 1.0 to 1.4, the resistivity slightly increases from 2.1Ã10â3Â Î©âcm to 2.6Ã10â3Â Î©âcm. Note that the sheet resistances for the ZnO:B films at different H2O/DEZ ratios are as follows: 170Â Î© (0.6), 13.3Â Î© (0.8), 12Â Î© (1.0), 13.4Â Î© (1.2) and 15Â Î© (1.4). The carrier concentration increases from 5.83Ã1019Â cmâ3 to 10Ã1019Â cmâ3 when the H2O/DEZ flow ratio increases further from 0.6 to 0.8 and then reduces to 7.9Ã1019Â cmâ3 for the further increasing of the H2O/DEZ flow ratio to 1.4. The first increase in carrier concentration could be attributed to more excited interstitial zinc atoms. However, a high H2O/DEZ ratio of more than 0.8 might lead to reductions in both interstitial zinc atoms and oxygen vacancies, which are in general beneficial to the carrier concentration. As a result, the carrier concentration slightly decreases for a relatively high H2O/DEZ ratio in this case as shown in Fig.Â 4b. As to the mobility, it increases from around 4.6Â cm2/V s to 35Â cm2/Vs when the H2O/DEZ flow ratio increases further from 0.6 to 1.0 and then slightly decreases to around 30Â cm2/V s with further increasing of the H2O/DEZ flow ratio to 1.4. The first enhancement in mobility could be due to a decrease in the scattering by the grain boundaries because of large-size grains as shown in Fig.Â 2b. However, more oxygen atoms might be chemically absorbed in the grain boundaries as defects at a high H2O/DEZ ratio of more than 1 and then cause a decrease in mobility as shown in Fig.Â 4b. Moreover, it was reported that a very high H2O/DEZ flow ratio could lead to formation of small-size grains and consequently a low mobility for the ZnO:B filmsÂ [17].
Fig.Â 4
Resistivity (a) and carrier concentration and mobility (b) of LPCVD ZnO:B films as a function of H2O/DEZ flow ratio. The lines are guides for the eyes. Moreover, the sheet resistances for the ZnO:B films at different H2O/DEZ ratios are as follows: 170Â Î© (0.6), 13.3Â Î© (0.8), 12Â Î© (1.0), 13.4Â Î© (1.2) and 15Â Î© (1.4)

FigureÂ 5 shows the TT and DT of the ZnO:B films deposited at the H2O/DEZ ratios of 0.6â1.4. The ZnO:B film deposited at an H2O/DEZ ratio of 0.6 shows a high TT over the whole wavelength range due to a low carrier concentration as mentioned above. When the H2O/DEZ ratio increases to more than 0.8 the TT reduces because of a high light absorption by the free carriers. In addition, the TT curves vary from wavy shapes to smooth curves due to light scattering by the rough surfaces of the ZnO:B films. The wavy shapes, i.e. interference fringes of the TT for the ZnO:B films at the low H2O/DEZ ratios, could be due to the relatively flat surface structures as shown in Fig.Â 2. Moreover, there exists a very slight BursteinâMoss shift in the absorption-edge region of TT in Fig.Â 5 due to different carrier concentrations. However, such a shift for the absorption edge of TT is not consistent with the change in carrier concentrations (see Fig.Â 4) due to the influence of the film thickness on TT. The DT increases with increasing H2O/DEZ ratio, which is in accordance with the variation of haze as shown in Fig.Â 6. The ZnO:B film deposited at H2O/DEZ ratios of 1.2 and 1.4 shows almost the same TT and DT. The inserted figure in Fig.Â 6 shows that the haze value at 600Â nm increases from 1.9Â % to about 28Â % with increasing H2O/DEZ ratio. All the observations in optical properties accord with the variations of morphologies of ZnO:B films as shown in Fig.Â 2. It should be noted that small-size grains formed at a very high H2O/DEZ flow ratio lead to a low hazeÂ [16].
Fig.Â 5
Total transmission (TT) and diffuse transmission (DT) of LPCVD ZnO:B films prepared at different H2O/DEZ ratios
Fig.Â 6
Haze of LPCVD ZnO:B films prepared at different H2O/DEZ ratios. The inserted figure shows the specific haze values at 600Â nm for these ZnO:B films

Section2.Heading: Application in solar cells
Section2.Para:
FigureÂ 7 shows the IâV performances of the a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H solar cells with ZnO:B front electrodes deposited at different H2O/DEZ ratios from 0.6 to 1.4. It is found that the efficiency increases with increasing H2O/DEZ ratio and then reaches a relatively constant value (10Â %) when the H2O/DEZ ratio is more than 1.2. The enhancement in efficiency is mainly attributed to the increase of the short-circuit current (J SC) while the open-circuit voltage (V OC) and fill factor (FF) remain relatively constant at 1.32 V and 70Â %, respectively. Differently, Nicolay et al.Â [16] reported that V OC and FF of single Î¼c-Si:H solar cells decrease with increasing H2O/DEZ ratio due to a high defect density caused by the sharper pyramidal surface of the ZnO:B front electrodes. In fact, the structure of a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H tandem solar cells is much more complicated than single Î¼c-Si:H solar cells, in which the bottom a-Si:H bottom solar cell is inserted between the ZnO:B front electrode and the bottom Î¼c-Si:H solar cell. As a result, the influence of the sharper pyramidal surface of the ZnO:B front electrodes on V OC and FF of a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H tandem solar cells is not so profound as single Î¼c-Si:H solar cells. In addition, even though the sheet resistance of ZnO:B films may influence FF of the solar cells to some extent, it was not observed here, which may be due to different matching states of the top and bottom currents for the top and bottom sub-cells as well as the quality of silicon materials as mentioned above. As to the increase of J SC, it is due to a good light trapping effect inside the solar cells with the rough ZnO:B films as front electrodes as shown in Fig.Â 2. The maximum J SC of 10.9 mA/cm2 is achieved for this type of tandem solar cell with a ZnO:B front electrode prepared at the high H2O/DEZ ratio of 1.4 as shown in Fig.Â 7a. Additionally, the further increase in H2O/DEZ ratio will lead to small pyramidal grains on the ZnO:B front electrode and consequently a low J SC as wellÂ [16].
Fig.Â 7
IâV parameters, i.e. efficiency and J SCÂ (a) as well as V OC and FF (b) of a-Si:H/c-Si:H tandem solar cells with LPCVD ZnO:B front electrodes prepared at different H2O/DEZ ratios from 0.6 to 1.4. The lines are guides for the eyes

FigureÂ 8 shows the light absorptions of a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H tandem solar cells and the spectral responses for the top a-Si:H cells and bottom Î¼c-Si:H cells tested by EQE measurements. The light absorption of a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H tandem solar cells shows a clear increase, in particular in the long-wavelength range, with increasing H2O/DEZ ratio from 0.6 to 1.2 and then reaches saturation. Such an observation could be caused by different light scattering effects of the ZnO:B films with different-roughness surface structures. Moreover, even though the carrier concentration of the ZnO:B film at an H2O/DEZ ratio of 0.6 is relatively small (see Fig.Â 4), the light harvesting at longer wavelengths is still low for the tandem solar cells here. It seems that such an effect is weaker compared to the light scattering effect for the ZnO:B film in this case. Corresponding to these absorption curves, the tandem solar cells show an enhanced spectral response (SR) at long wavelengths of 600â1000 nm and resulting high J SC values for the bottom solar cells as shown in Figs.Â 8 andÂ 9. As to the low SR at short wavelengths of 400â500 nm and the low J SC values for the top cells as shown in Fig.Â 8, it could be due to a relatively thicker p-layer grown on the relatively smooth ZnO:B front electrodesÂ [2]. In addition, the low light scattering effect by the smooth ZnO:B front electrodes could also lead to a low SR at wavelengths of 500â800 nm for the top cells. As shown in Fig.Â 9, the J SC values for both top and bottom cells increase with increasing H2O/DEZ ratio and reach saturated values in this study here. Moreover, the J SC values of top cells are higher than those of bottom cells for individual tandem solar cells, which means that the current matching status for top and bottom cells could be optimized further to enhance the efficiency of the tandem solar cells. Such observations are in accordance with the variations of J SC values tested by IâV measurement as shown in Fig.Â 7a although the J SC values are slightly higher than those tested by EQE measurements.
Fig.Â 8
EQE results and absorptions of a-Si:H/c-Si:H tandem solar cells with LPCVD ZnO:B front electrodes prepared at different H2O/DEZ ratios from 0.6 to 1.4. White PVB foils were employed as dielectric back light reflectors for all solar cells
Fig.Â 9
J SC values of top and bottom cells for a-Si:H/c-Si:H tandem solar cells as a function of the H2O/DEZ ratio. The lines are guides for the eyes

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: ZnO:B films were deposited at different H2O/DEZ flow ratios from 0.6 to 1.4 by the LPCVD technique. The morphology varies from small leaf-like to pyramidal surface structures with the increasing H2O/DEZ flow ratios. Relatively high H2O/DEZ flow ratios lead to a highly rough surface structure and consequently a high light scattering property. A high haze value of up to 28Â % was achieved at the H2O/DEZ flow ratios of 1.2 and 1.4. The efficiency of a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H solar cells increases with increasing H2O/DEZ flow ratio, which is mainly attributed to a high SR especially in the long-wavelength range and the consequent enhancement of J SC. A high efficiency of 10Â % was achieved for the a-Si:H/Î¼c-Si:H tandem solar cells with the rough ZnO:B front electrodes. The H2O/DEZ ratio is an important process parameter to tune the material properties of LPCVD ZnO:B films as well as the device performances of corresponding silicon thin film solar cells.
